addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord, the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

21 May
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
Zutphen.
/

page.lettertext:
fol.64r
May it please yo
r
good L. I declared in
my last
e 17 of this moneth, what practise
was used by
S
r
Francis Vere
, whereby he
surprised
e sconce before Zutphen.
Certaine of his souldiers were disguised
like boores and barins, who being assisted
w
t
e company of contrey boores, and fai-
ning to runne for succo
r
to
e sconce, bring
i
g
w
t
them corne and other victualles, as they
had often done before, were receaved by
the Garrison, and folowed w
t
suche dili-
gence by S
r
Francis Vere, as all w
t
in the
fort, w
ch
were not passing 30 persons,
were put to
e sworde, and
e fort taken.
This was done
e 14 day of this present,
in
e morning. The night folowing he dispo-
sed his troupes, to inclose
e towne of Zutphen,
and sent w
t
all to
Count Maurice
, being
then at
Utrecht,
to seconde him presently
w
t
further forces: who caused 3 Cornets of
horse, and 11 Enseignes of foote to marche
w
t
all diligence towardes Zutphen: and
he himself folowed
e next day after, w
t
e rest of his troupes, and provision of
shippes, bridges, and roweboates. The
same day
e Enemie in a furie attempted
e recoverie of
e fort, but failed of his
purpose. Also those of
Deventer
ende-
vouring to relieve
e towne of Zutphen
fol.64v
w
t
a 100 horse laden w
t
corne, were over-
throwen by o
r
souldiers, who had also the
spoile of their corne and horse. Howbeit,
the
Count of Overstein
in going to make a
bravado before
e towne, was overtaken by
an ambushe of
e Enemie, and shotte
e
head, wherof he died presently. S
r
Francis Vere
being w
t
him escaped very happely: but
his horse was stricken. By this time it is
thought, that
e Count hath planted his articl-
lerie, to batter
e towne: w
ch
is all
e oc-
currence,
at is yet at
e Hage.
And so
I take my humble leave. At
e Hage
May 21 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
